citation.abstract: A type of highly photoluminescent gel-like carbon dots (G-CDs) was successfully synthesized for the first time, by a rapid one-step solvothermal synthesis approach with citric acid and 1, 2-ethylenediamine (EDA) as the precursors. Their gel-like nature was revealed by the Tyndall and coagulation effect which was elucidated by their negative Zeta potential value. The influence of temperatures on the properties and sizes of these G-CDs was analyzed and the best method for maximum quantum yield (QY) was identified. The resulting products emitted blue photoluminescence (PL) under UV light (365 nm) and a gradient of color in the regular light. In addition, UV-Vis absorption and excitation-dependent fluorescence spectra of G-CDs indicated those synthesized at 160 ℃ exhibited the highest fluorescence quantum yield (33%). AFM and TEM measurements were performed and higher temperature of formation resulted in smaller G-CDs. Furthermore, peak shifts in the UV-Vis and fluorescence spectra, and sequential change of quantum yield values, Zeta potential and XPS elemental compositional changes synchronously effectively monitored throughout G-CDs formation process. As to application, G-CDs were prepared as invisible ink for printer, which exhibited applicability of G-CDs in daily life or military activities.

publisher_subjects.name: Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, Particle And Plasma Physics

citation.title: Gel-like Carbon Dots, Characterization, and their Potential Applications

author.name: ChemPhysChem
